QUALITY
Westerns were irregular, whilst the Nuwara Eliyas were not up to expectations. A small selection of Uvas were improved, whilst the others together with the Uda Pussellawas showed no change. Low Growns were similar to last.
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 2
Page 2
COMMENTS
Auction offerings totalled 6.0 M/Kgs. Low Grown/Large Leaf teas continued to meet with good demand, whilst the High & Mid Grown liquoring BOP/BOPF's encountered less demand to last.
Ex-Estate offerings were maintained around 0.75 M/Kgs. Overall quality of teas from the Western slopes perhaps were not as useful as the previous week, whilst the Nuwara Eliya's were not up to expectations. A select range of improved seasonal Uva's were on offer.
In the Western High Grown category, Best Western BOP's were easier by Rs. 50 per kg and more for last week's high-priced teas. Corresponding BOPF's, whilst a few select invoices sold around last levels, others often declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more following quality. In the Below Best category, BOP's - High-priced teas of last week were firm and easier, whilst the others were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's, where quality was maintained, prices were firm, whilst the others declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg. At the lower end, BOP's declined by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the corresponding BOPF's were Rs. 20-30 per kg lower. Nuwara Eliyas' were mostly unsold due to a lack of suitable bids. Uda Pussellawas' were irregular and easier. Uva - Seasonal BOP's sold between Rs. 2,000-3,100 per kg, whilst the corresponding BOPF's sold between Rs. 2,000-2,250 per kg. Others non-seasonal BOP's were barely steady, whilst the corresponding BOPF's declined by up to Rs. 50 per kg.
High & Medium Grown CTC teas continued to sell around last subject to price fluctuations following quality. Corresponding Low Grown BP1's - A few select invoices were dearer, whilst the others sold around last. PF1's - Better teas were firm and marginally dearer, whilst the secondary types were marginally easier.
Low Growns totalled approximately 2.4 M/Kgs. All categories met with fair demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, well-made BOP1's were firm, whilst the Below Best together with the bolder varieties were irregular. Teas at the bottom maintained.  Select Best and Best  OP1's sold around last levels, whilst the balance were irregular. Well-made OP/OPA's appreciated, whilst the balance sold around last levels. Select Best PEK's maintained, whilst the Best together with the mixed/open varieties declined. High-priced PEK1's were easier, whilst the balance were fully firm.
In the Tippy catalogue, Select Best FBOP's sold around last levels, whilst the balance were firm to dearer. However, the bolder varieties declined. Select Best and Best FF1's together with the cleaner Below Best varieties were firm to dearer, whilst the balance were irregular following quality.
In the Premium catalogue, very Tippy teas were firm on last, whilst the Best and Below Best appreciated. Balance were firm.
NOTE
Next week's Auction (Sale No. 30) is scheduled for Monday, 4 August and Tuesday, 5 August 2025
FORBES & WALKER TEA BROKERS (PVT) LTD SALE OF - 29TH/ 30TH JULY 2025
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 3
Page 3
MARKET
Less demand
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Best Western's were irregular and easier by up to Rs. 50 per kg and more for last week's select high-priced teas. In the Below Best category, select high-priced teas were firm and easier, whilst the others were irregular following quality. Teas at the lower end were firm and Rs. 20 per kg easier. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were irregularly easier and mostly unsold. Best Uva's (seasonal) sold well between Rs. 2,000-3,000 per kg, whilst the others were barely steady.
BOPF
Best Western's - A few select invoices sold around last week's levels, whilst the others declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more following quality. In the Below Best category, where quality was maintained, prices were firm, whilst the others declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Teas at the lower end were firm and Rs. 20-30 per kg easier following quality. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were irregular and easier. Uva's - Seasonal teas sold well between Rs. 2,000-2,250 per kg, whilst the others declined by up to Rs. 50 per kg.
OP/OPA
Well-made varieties were firm on last levels, whilst the others and poorer sorts were firm to easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
Flavoury PEK's were easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the Orthodox Leafy PEK's were firm. Best PEK1's were dearer by Rs. 50-100 per kg and more at times. Teas at the lower end were firm to easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Best Rotovane PEK's remained mostly firm to irregularly easier by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts declined following quality.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Select Best flavoury FBOP/FBOPF1's were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the poorer sorts were firm. Better Orthodox FBOP/FBOPF1's appreciated by Rs. 30-50 per kg, whilst the others and teas at the lower end held firm.

OFF GRADES
FGS1/FGS
Teas in the Best category were dearer by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the improved Below Best varieties followed a similar trend and gained by Rs. 25-50 per kg. The balance were firm on last levels. Teas at the bottom end of the market maintained. Low Growns - Best  varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 10-20 per kg. Below Best varieties maintained,  whilst the poorer sorts were irregular. CTC's - In general, declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg.
BROKENS
Reducer varieties in the Best category together with the clean leaf sorts maintained, whilst the balance appreciated by Rs. 10-20 per kg.
BOP1A
Main Grade reducer varieties in the Best category were firm, whilst select invoices gained following quality. Below Best varieties eased by Rs. 20-30 per kg and more on occasion, whilst the poorer sorts in general were maintained.

The Below Best types, where quality was maintained, were dearer by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the others together with the poorer sorts remained firm. Low Grown Best varieties were dearer by Rs. 60 per kg, whilst the Below Best varieties and the poorer sorts were dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg. High and Medium Grown CTC's together with the Low Grown CTCs were firm all round.
DUST
Clean leaf secondaries were dearer by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the poorer sorts remained firm. The Low Grown Best varieties appreciated by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the others were dearer by Rs. 20-30 per kg.

CROP AND WEATHER
For the period 23 - 29 July 2025
Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions
Rain was reported in both regions throughout the week. The Department of Meteorology expects rain in the Western and Nuwara Eliya regions in the week ahead.
Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions
Bright weather was reported in both regions throughout the week. According to the Department of Meteorology, showers/thunder showers are expected in both regions in the week ahead.
Low Growns
The Low Grown Region reported bright mornings and occasional evening showers throughout the week. Intermittent showers are expected in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead according to the Department of Meteorology.
Crop Intake
The Nuwara Eliya Region reported an increase in the crop intake, whilst the Western, Uva, Uda Pussellawa and Low Grown regions reported a decrease.

MOMBASA AUCTION
SALE OF - 28TH and 29TH JULY 2025 (SALE NO. 30)
There was good general demand for the 186,120 packages (12,632,701.00 kilos) available in the market; 45.26% remained unsold.
MARKETS
Pakistan Packers were active while Yemen and other Middle Eastern countries lent strong support . There was reduced activity from Kazakhstan and other CIS states with maintained enquiry from Afghanistan and Bazaar. Egyptian Packers showed more and strong interest with UK active but selective; Russia improved absorption. Sudan were absent while South Sudan maintained activity. Local Packers reduced interest while Somalia were active at the lower end of the market.
OFFERINGS
Leaf Grades               -    97,000 packages (6,393,906.00 kilos) - 52.23% unsold.
Dust Grades             -    71,140 packages (5,310,489.00 kilos) - 44.36% unsold.
Secondary Grades     -    17,980 packages ( 928,306.00 kilos) - 11.23% unsold.
LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3) BP1:
Best - Irregular enquiry and varied between USC29 dearer to easier by up to USC18 with most teas remaining unsold.
Brighter - Saw irregular interest and ranged between steady to USC20 dearer to easier by up to USC27. Mediums - KTDA mediums were firm to USC10 dearer to USC8 below previous levels with plantation mediums firm to USC37 dearer for some lines to easier by up to USC20.
Lower Medium - More irregular and ranged between steady to USC16 dearer to easier by up to USC20.
Plainer - Easier by up to USC9 but select teas gained up to USC6.
PF1:
Best - More irregular and varied between USC22 above previous levels to easier by up to USC27.
Brighter - Were irregular and ranged between USC7 dearer to USC12 below last levels.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were firm to USC11 dearer to easier by up to USC10; Plantation medium were irregular ranging between USC12 dearer to USC8 below previous rates.
Lower Medium - Were firm to USC9 above previous rates to USC8 easier.
Plainer - More irregular interest and varied between USC4 dearer to mostly easier by up to USC15.

Lower Medium - Irregular ranging between firm to USC6 dearer to easier by up to USC5.
Plainer - Were up to USC5 above previous rates to easier by up to USC3.

In the Secondary Catalogues, BPs were firm with better made sorts dearer; PFs sold at about previous rates. BANGLADESH AUCTION
SALE OF - 28TH JULY 2025 (SALE NO. 12)
CTC LEAF: 53,930 packages of tea on offer continued to meet with a strong demand.
BROKENS: All good liquoring Brokens were strongly competed for and prices were fully firm to touch dearer for selective lots. Withdrawals were negligible in this category. Mediums were firm. Plain descriptions met with some demand and were about steady but there were several withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good demand and were generally firm to occasionally dearer. There were a few withdrawals.
FANNINGS: Best and good Fannings were a strong feature and were mostly firm whilst Mediums saw a steady demand and prices were also firm on last. Plain varieties saw less demand there were many more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good demand and were generally firm to occasionally dearer. There were several withdrawals.
DUST: 13,064 packages of tea on offer met with good demand Good liquoring Dusts sold well at around last levels Medium and plainer sorts were discounted and witnessed fair weight of withdrawals. BLFs continued to meet with a better demand with only a few withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.
COMMENTS: Blenders continued to operate strongly but there was less support from the Loose tea buyers. Buyers once again followed quality closely whereby a selection of plainer types were neglected and were subject to withdrawals.
Dusts sold well.
Our Catalogue: (Sale 12) Avg : Tk 250.85, Sold 76.49% , (Sale 11) Avg : Tk 251.02, Sold 83.40%

KOLKATA SALE  CTC MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to good demand. Liquoring Assams irregular around last levels. Medium and plainer sorts tending easier. Dooars seen so far similar trend.
BUYING PATTERN:
Western India - Supporting the better teas on offer
HUL - Operating
West Bengal Manufacturing - Selective so far
Exporters - Fair enquiry
Other local/internal - Operating
KOLKATA SALE  ORTHODOX MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to strong demand. Few tippy teas on offer sold readily. Well made Whole Leaf and Brokens selling at firm rates. Remainder Whole Leaf and Brokens irregular around last following quality. Fannings and Cleaner Secondaries selling around last levels.
BUYING PATTERN:
Middle East : Active
CIS:  Good Support
HUL: Selective
KOLKATA SALE  DUST MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to good demand. Liquoring sorts around last levels. Remainder barely
steady and at times easier following quality.
BUYING PATTERN:
HUL: Active
West Bengal Manufacturing: Operating
Western India: Good Support
Local and Internal: Some enquiry.
Courtesy - J Thomas & Company Private
JAKARTA AUCTION
SALE OF - 25TH JULY 2025 (SALE NO. 30)
The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 76.43%(1,225,405.47kgs) of the total offering of 1,603,275.35Kgs
DEMAND: - Good and improved demand on all sorts except for the lower medium and plainer teas which continue to meet with selective or rather reduced demand.
MARKET: - The best, good & better medium teas sold at firm to dearer prices. Medium sorts stabilized at barely steady levels, except for the fanning grade which saw a slight decline in prices. Select plain teas held on to last levels however, bulk of this category especially browner and fibrous sorts continued to face withdrawals.
BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders continued to be the mainstay of the CTC market with 45.66% off take with fair support from the Western India packer. Local & regional packers were active on the best and good liquoring sorts. Internal buyers continued to be subdued. Russian and CIS exporters along with the Middle east shippers increased their purchases especially on blacker sorts. Iraqi shippers too were fairly active.
ORTHODOX LEAF
Demand:- Fair Demand.
Market:- High grown whole leaf with good make and blacker sorts were firm to dearer. Others were Rs 2 to 3 easier. Medium grown whole leaf sold irregularly, with cleaner broken ruling firm market. Fanning eased in value.
Buying Pattern:- CIS buyers were selective on cleaner blacker varieties along with Internal buyers.Middle east shippers lent fair support on whole leaf grades and broken.
CTC DUST
DEMAND: - Good improved demand. Reduced demand for the lower medium and plainers..
MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 484,220.66Kgs of which 372464.96kgs were sold (76.92%). Best & good teas sold dearer in line with quality. Better medium & medium teas sold at fully firm rates. Select lower medium and plainer teas sold at last levels however the browner sorts continued to face withdrawals.
BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were fairly active. Regional and local packers were active on the best & good teas. Up country buyers were subdued. Exporters to Russia, Middle east improved their purchases this week on blacker sorts.
ORTHODOX DUST
DEMAND: - Good demand.
MARKET: - High grown primary dust fetched irregular prices following quality, medium grown sold irregularly easier. Secondaries were barely steady.
BUYING PATTERN: -Regional & local packateers were fairly active on primary dusts. Exporters were very choosy at steady prices on the secondary dusts.
Courtesy -J Thomas & Company Private Limited
